study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a single 100 mg dose of sildenafil compared to placebo in improving maximal walking time (MWT) in patients with claudication due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that a single 100 mg dose of sildenafil significantly improved MWT compared to placebo but had no significant effect on pain-free walking time or skin tissue oxygenation. Sildenafil also reduced blood glucose and pyruvate levels but showed no significant effect on other redox cycle parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) experiencing claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether real-time visual biofeedback during treadmill training could increase minimum toe clearance (MTC) in stroke survivors to reduce tripping risk.
results_summary: The study proposed a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effect of biofeedback on MTC, with gait assessments and falls monitoring over 12 months, but results were not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults aged >18 years with a single chronic stroke (≥6 months prior), able to walk 50m independently.
effective_dosage: 10 treadmill training sessions (up to 10 min each) over 5-6 weeks.
study_duration: 5-6 weeks (intervention), with follow-up assessments up to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefit and safety of venous percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) in people with multiple sclerosis (MS) and chronic cerebrospinal venous insufficiency (CCSVI).
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit of venous PTA on patient-centered outcomes such as disability, physical or cognitive functions, relapses, or quality of life compared to sham procedures. Venous PTA was safe but ineffective in restoring blood flow or improving MS symptoms.
population_specificity: Adults with MS and CCSVI
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 6 to 12 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether iron repletion improved congestion in chronic heart failure (CHF) patients and evaluated the prognostic utility of calculated plasma volume status (PVS).
results_summary: Intravenous iron therapy (ferric carboxymaltose) was associated with early reductions in PVS and weight, suggesting decongestion as a potential mechanism for symptom improvement. Patients with decreased PVS showed greater improvements in 6-minute walking distance and NYHA class.
population_specificity: Iron-deficient chronic heart failure patients (n=459, analyzed n=436).
effective_dosage: Intravenous ferric carboxymaltose (specific dosage not mentioned in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of return to normal neurological function after surgery for moderate or severe degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM), focusing on factors like walking time.
results_summary: The study found that longer walking time on the 30-m walking test was an independent predictor of a lower likelihood of achieving normal neurological function post-surgery for DCM. The model had an area under the curve of 0.71, indicating moderate predictive accuracy.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate or severe degenerative cervical myelopathy (baseline mJOA ≤ 14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating photobiomodulation (PBM) into a physical exercise program improves pain, muscle strength, and physical capacity in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both exercise groups (with or without PBM) showed significant pain reduction, improved walking distance (6-MWT), and increased muscle strength (MVIT). PBM did not provide additional benefits beyond exercise alone for these outcomes.
population_specificity: 62 female volunteers with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 16 sessions of lower limb strength exercises and PBM (808 nm, 100 mW, 7 points each side, 56 J total).
study_duration: Duration of 16 sessions (exact timeframe not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of robotic-assisted gait training on ambulation and functional capacity in patients with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvement in functional ambulation and independence, but the robotic-assisted gait training group demonstrated significantly higher improvements compared to the conventional therapy group.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal cord injury (n=88).
effective_dosage: 16 sessions of robotic therapy training over 8 weeks, plus conventional therapy 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine changes in power production of bilateral ankles, knees, and hips during level walking and stair climbing before and after unilateral THA, and whether these changes were gender-specific.
results_summary: The study found that THA increased hip power production on the surgical side during walking and stair climbing, while reducing compensatory power production in other joints, with no consistent gender differences observed.
population_specificity: 13 men and 13 women who underwent primary, unilateral THA and could walk and climb stairs without assistive devices.
study_duration: Preoperative, 6 weeks postoperative, and 1 year postoperative assessments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and automated assessment of neurological gait disorders, focusing on vestibular, cerebellar, and functional gait impairments, and how instrumented gait examination can aid diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring.
results_summary: The study found that instrumented gait examination and standardized assessment protocols can help characterize and interpret walking impairments, particularly under challenging conditions, and highlighted the potential of pattern recognition approaches for clinical decision-making in gait disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological gait disorders (vestibular, cerebellar, and functional gait impairments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and feasibility of the Atrial Flow Regulator (AFR) device in heart failure patients, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that AFR device implantation was feasible and safe, with 100% procedural success and shunt patency at three months. Some patients showed improvement in heart failure symptoms and surrogate parameters, though not all.
population_specificity: Symptomatic heart failure patients (NYHA Class III or IV) with either reduced or preserved ejection fraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait characteristics between bilateral and unilateral total hip arthroplasty (THA) patients and assess differences between these groups and asymptomatic healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that bilateral THA patients showed improved pelvic tilt and gait phases compared to unilateral THA patients post-surgery, but reported higher pain scores. Both patient groups had impaired gait parameters compared to healthy subjects before and after surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with bilateral (n=18) or unilateral THA (n=17) and asymptomatic age-matched volunteers (n=20).
study_duration: Evaluated the day before surgery and at seven days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of brisk walking versus Baduanjin on cognitive function in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Brisk walking did not show significant improvements in MoCA scores compared to the control group, while Baduanjin demonstrated better cognitive outcomes. The study also found no significant neuroimaging changes in the brisk walking group compared to Baduanjin or control groups.
population_specificity: 69 patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency/duration implied by intervention length).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic efficacy and functional outcomes of adductor canal block (ACB) versus local infiltration analgesia (LIA) after ACL reconstruction, with a focus on postoperative pain and walking-related functional recovery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between ACB and LIA in postoperative opioid consumption, pain scores, or functional outcomes, including walking distance, at 24 and 48 hours post-operation, as well as at 4 and 8 months. Both techniques provided equivalent analgesia and similar functional recovery.
population_specificity: 104 patients undergoing ACL reconstruction under general anesthesia.
effective_dosage: Ropivacaine 0.5%, 20 ml (single injection for each intervention).
study_duration: Postoperative outcomes measured up to 8 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how moderate-intensity small-sided walking football games (SWF) affect inhibitory control and neurophysiological measures of attention in children compared to high-intensity football games and resting.
results_summary: The study found that high-intensity football games (SRF) improved inhibitory control more than moderate-intensity walking football games (SWF), with no significant effects on declarative memory. Neurophysiological measures showed larger increases in P300 amplitudes for SRF compared to SWF and resting.
population_specificity: 81 children (mean age 11.8, 48 boys) in a school setting.
effective_dosage: 20-minute session of moderate-intensity small-sided walking football games.
study_duration: Single 20-minute intervention with follow-up assessments at 20 minutes and 7 days post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a supervised exercise program on quality of life, walking impairment, and Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) in individuals with Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The review found insufficient data to determine the effectiveness of supervised exercise programs for PAD with T2DM, as the included studies varied in their exercise programs and outcomes, and no consistent results were reported.
population_specificity: Individuals with Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a single session of tDCS over the primary motor cortex of the lower limb (M1-LL) vs. placebo on walking performance in chronic hemiplegic patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant positive effect of 25% on walking performance (6MWT) 1 hour after anodal tDCS stimulation compared to sham, though no significant differences were observed for other evaluations like gait parameters or balance.
population_specificity: Chronic hemiplegic patients with poststroke delay >6 months.
study_duration: Single session with assessments during and 1 hour after stimulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of combined intermittent aerobic, muscle strength, and home-based walking training on cardiorespiratory fitness in women with breast cancer during adjuvant chemotherapy.
results_summary: The trained group showed significant improvements in walking speed, walking distance, heart rate, blood lactate concentration, and perceived exertion compared to controls, indicating enhanced cardiorespiratory fitness and reduced fatigue perception.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (home-based walking training program details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term safety and tolerability of PRM-151 and its effects on percentage of predicted FVC and 6-min walking distance in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
results_summary: Long-term treatment with PRM-151 was well tolerated, with adverse events consistent with IPF sequelae. PRM-151 showed persistent treatment effects, reducing decline in FVC and stabilizing 6-min walking distance in both continued and crossover patients.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg by 60 min intravenous infusions on days 1, 3, and 5 in the first week of each 28-week cycle, followed by one infusion every 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of Zephyr valves for endoscopic lung volume reduction in patients with severe emphysema without collateral ventilation.
results_summary: Zephyr valves improved lung function (FEV1), walking distance (6MWT), quality of life (SGRQ), and residual volume (RV), but increased the risk of pneumothorax.
population_specificity: Patients with severe emphysema without collateral ventilation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether co-careldopa, combined with routine occupational and physical therapy, improves walking ability in stroke patients during early rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that co-careldopa improved walking independence compared to placebo at 8 weeks. Adverse events, such as vomiting, were more frequent in the co-careldopa group, but serious adverse events and mortality rates were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with new or recurrent ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke (excluding subarachnoid hemorrhage), 5-42 days post-stroke, unable to walk 10 m or more, with a Rivermead Mobility Index score <7.
effective_dosage: Initial two doses of 62.5 mg (50 mg levodopa + 12.5 mg carbidopa), followed by 125 mg (100 mg levodopa + 25 mg carbidopa), taken 45-60 min before therapy sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether daily cane use during walking for 3 months could reduce medial tibiofemoral bone marrow lesion (BML) volumes in people with medial tibiofemoral osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in BML volume changes between the cane-use group and the control group after 3 months. Most secondary outcomes also showed minimal differences between the groups.
population_specificity: 79 participants with medial tibiofemoral osteoarthritis (OA).
effective_dosage: Mean daily cane use was 2.3 (1.7) hours over 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to adapt and validate the Manchester-Oxford Foot Questionnaire (MOXFQ) into Chinese for assessing patients with hallux valgus.
results_summary: The MOXFQ-Chinese Version demonstrated excellent internal consistency (0.976-0.991) and moderate to excellent external validity, supported by correlations with other validated questionnaires (Short-Form 12v2, Foot Function Index, EuroQol-5D). The psychometric properties were robust, indicating its suitability for clinical and research use in Chinese-speaking populations.
population_specificity: 369 patients (241 women, 128 men; mean age 48.75 ± 8.17 years) diagnosed with hallux valgus (237 both feet, 74 right foot, 58 left foot).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of adductor canal block (ACB) using levobupivacaine versus periarticular levobupivacaine infiltration (PAI-L) in managing postoperative pain and improving knee range of motion and walking ability after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: ACB-L was more effective in reducing postoperative pain and morphine consumption, while PAI-L showed better results in improving knee range of motion and walking ability. Both methods demonstrated statistically significant differences in their respective outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients aged 40-85 years undergoing unilateral TKA.
effective_dosage: PAI-L group: 40 ml (0.125 mg) of levobupivacaine; ACB-L group: 20 ml of 0.25% levobupivacaine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of autologous stem cell implantation compared to conventional therapy for treating peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in "no-option" patients.
results_summary: Autologous stem cell therapy showed significant improvements in ulcer healing rate, ankle-brachial index, transcutaneous oxygen tension, pain-free walking distance, and reduced amputation rates and rest pain scores, but no significant improvement in major limb salvage. No serious side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with critical peripheral arterial disease (PAD) who were "no-option" candidates for surgery or interventional therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare four methods of load progression in resistance training (RT) for older adults to determine the optimal approach for improving strength and functional performance.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in strength or functional performance outcomes (including walking speed) between the four RT load progression methods, but the RPE method was rated as more tolerable and enjoyable by participants.
population_specificity: Healthy community-dwelling older adults (mean age 71.8 ± 6.2 years).
effective_dosage: 2.5 days per week of structured resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) on walking ability (measured by the 6-minute walking test) and respiratory function in late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that ERT improved respiratory function and walking distance in the 6-minute walking test, with results confirmed by retrospective, prospective observations, and meta-analyses. However, the efficacy was described as moderate, and optimal timing for ERT initiation and cessation remains debated.
population_specificity: Patients with late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the minimal clinically important difference (MCID) in decline in the WOMAC hip/knee physical function scores over 1 year, using anchor-based and distribution-based methods.
results_summary: The study found that the MCID for decline in the WOMAC hip/knee physical function score was 2 points, with changes in this score significantly correlated with changes in pain and stiffness scores. Walking speed was used as one of the anchors, but the abstract does not detail specific walking-related outcomes.
population_specificity: Six adult cohorts with and without osteoarthritis (OA) from the European Project on Osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of a physical activity intervention (including walking) for improving fitness, physical activity levels, and disease-specific symptoms in people with Huntington disease (HD).
results_summary: The study will evaluate the feasibility of long-term physical activity interventions in HD, focusing on aerobic exercise and increased physical activity, with assessments of fitness, walking endurance, and disease symptoms. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Early-mid-stage Huntington disease (HD) patients participating in the Enroll-HD study.
effective_dosage: 18 sessions of physical activity behavioral change intervention delivered by physical therapists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how patients with multiple sclerosis perceive gait impairment over the first year of natalizumab treatment and to identify objective correlates of this change.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in subjective gait perception (MSWS-12 score) and objective gait parameters (walking velocity, step length, and double support time) after 12 months of natalizumab treatment. These improvements were statistically significant (p < 0.001) and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: 50 patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis, median EDSS 3.5 (range 1.5-5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of environmental and behavioral interventions in promoting active commuting to work (ACW), specifically walking and cycling.
results_summary: The study found that promoting ACW through environmental improvements and social-behavioral strategies had measurable impacts, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. Data collection methods included questionnaires, travel diaries, and accelerometers.
population_specificity: Employees from 16 Finnish workplaces (total n=2649).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) versus NSAIDs in reducing pain and improving knee function in patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: ESWT showed statistically significant improvements in pain (VAS) and knee function (WOMAC) at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-treatment, with gait analysis indicating functional recovery. No significant differences were found between ESWT and NSAIDs at 4 and 8 weeks.
population_specificity: 82 patients with KOA receiving ESWT and 104 patients with KOA receiving NSAIDs.
effective_dosage: ESWT parameters: 2.0 bar, 0.25 mJ/mm², 8 Hz/s, twice weekly.
study_duration: 4 weeks of treatment, with follow-ups up to 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Botulinum Toxin A (BT) improves gait velocity, walking ability, balance, mobility, lower limb function, and quality of life in post-stroke patients with lower limb spasticity.
results_summary: The study is designed to assess the effectiveness of BT in improving walking and related functions, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The methodology suggests a rigorous evaluation of multiple functional outcomes.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients with lower limb spasticity (n=94).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence, clinical course, current therapy, and mortality in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) in the National Registry.
results_summary: The study found that the 6-minute walking test distance was 361.3±129.3 m, and 65% of PAH patients had functional class III/IV at diagnosis. Survival rates were 98.9% at 1 year, 94.1% at 3 years, and 86.0% at 5 years.
population_specificity: Patients over 18 years of age with diagnosed PAH, including idiopathic PAH, drug- and toxin-induced PAH, inherited PAH, and PAH associated with various conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect and safety of combined enalapril and metoprolol treatment on delaying cardiomyopathy progression in DMD patients with preserved left ventricular function.
results_summary: The study found a non-significant trend favoring the medication group over placebo in delaying left ventricular function deterioration. Secondary outcomes showed time-dependent worsening of cardiac function but no significant differences between groups. One adverse event involved reversible walking ability deterioration in a patient during the run-in period.
population_specificity: DMD boys aged 10-14 years with preserved left ventricular function (LV-FS ≥ 30%).
study_duration: 16 weeks run-in, followed by randomized treatment until study end (approximately 19 months post-randomization).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of combining Rotarex thrombectomy and drug-coated balloon angioplasty for treating femoropopliteal artery in-stent restenosis, with a focus on walking improvement.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in ankle-brachial index and Walking Impairment Questionnaire scores at 12 months, with high primary patency (86.2%) and freedom from target lesion revascularization (89.7%).
population_specificity: 32 patients with femoropopliteal artery in-stent restenosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Wii Fit balance board as an additional tool for exercise training in patients with COPD compared to standard cycle ergometer training.
results_summary: Both the control group (cycle ergometer) and the experimental group (Wii Fit) showed significant improvements in six-minute walking distance, transitional dyspnea index, and Saint George's Respiratory Questionnaire scores, but no significant differences were found between the two groups. The Wii Fit program was feasible but did not provide additional benefits over standard exercise training.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: Exercise training three times a week (cycle ergometer for the control group, Wii Fit program including yoga, strength training, and aerobic exercise for the experimental group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in HIV-infected patients, their risk factors, and their impact on quality of life, with walking time as one of the criteria for frailty assessment.
results_summary: The study found that frailty and pre-frailty were prevalent in HIV-infected patients, with slow walking time being one of the Fried's criteria used to assess frailty. Frail patients had higher comorbidity indices and poorer quality of life indicators.
population_specificity: HIV-infected adults aged ≥18 years on stable antiretroviral therapy for ≥1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether implanted peroneal functional electrical stimulation (FES) improves gait adaptability (specifically obstacle avoidance) compared to ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) in stroke patients with drop foot.
results_summary: Success rates for obstacle avoidance were higher with FES than AFO (4.7% improvement, p=0.03), particularly for longer response times (15% improvement, p=0.03). Participants with greater motor impairment showed greater benefits from FES.
population_specificity: 22 stroke patients (>6 months post-stroke) with drop foot who regularly used an AFO.
study_duration: Up to 26 weeks (n=10) or 52 weeks (n=12) after FES activation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) versus conventional over-ground walking training (CGT) in people with multiple sclerosis, based on their level of disability.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in walking performance between RAGT and CGT, with small and non-significant effect sizes for both short and long-distance tests. Neither baseline walking speed nor disease-related disability predicted the effectiveness of the interventions.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis, classified by disability level using the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and radiological outcomes of endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) in elderly patients with obstructive chronic hydrocephalus (OCH), focusing on walking, autonomy, and incontinence.
results_summary: The study found that 14 out of 15 patients showed significant improvement in clinical scores (Larsson's score decreased from 3.8 to 0.6) and slight improvement in cognitive function (MMSE increased from 25.7 to 28). Ventricular size decreased postoperatively, and no complications were observed.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with obstructive chronic hydrocephalus (OCH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of adaptive goal-setting and incentive interventions for increasing moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) adoption and maintenance over 2 years among adults from neighborhoods varying in walkability.
results_summary: The study tested adaptive interventions against static-goal-setting and delayed-incentive comparisons in a factorial randomized trial, hypothesizing that higher-walkable neighborhoods would enhance MVPA intervention effects, though specific results on Walking's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 512 healthy, insufficiently-active adults (64.3% female, mean age 45.5 ± 9.1 years, mean BMI 33.9 ± 7.3 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether visual attention training could improve balance and mobility in older adults, potentially reducing fall risk.
results_summary: The study found no improvement in mobility or balance after visual attention training, with no significant differences between the intervention and control groups.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults aged 70+ (mean age 80.3 ± 6 years).
effective_dosage: Visual attention training twice a week (45-minute sessions) for 3 weeks (six sessions total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical activity levels and walking behavior in hospitalized patients with musculoskeletal pain, assess the influence of pain site, and measure the association between physical activity and pain-related interference.
results_summary: Rehabilitation days showed significantly higher physical activity and walking durations compared to days off, with a negative association between physical activity and pain interference but no effect of pain sites. Patients increased physical activity independently of reported pain interference.
population_specificity: 272 inpatients with lower limb, spine, or upper limb pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of single-shot versus continuous adductor canal block techniques in improving pain control, functional recovery, and ambulation outcomes in total knee arthroplasty patients.
results_summary: The study found that continuous adductor canal block provided better pain control, reduced need for rescue analgesia, and improved functional recovery (e.g., faster active straight-leg rise, better 6-minute walking test performance, and greater knee flexion at discharge) compared to single-shot adductor canal block. No significant differences were observed in other functional and ambulation scores.
population_specificity: 123 patients scheduled for unilateral primary total knee arthroplasty (mean age ~67 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (comparison of single-shot vs. continuous infusion techniques).
study_duration: Postoperative period until discharge (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of treadmill gait training with varying inclinations on functional and cardiovascular variables in patients with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that treadmill training, especially with anterior inclination, could improve exercise capacity, reduce blood pressure and heart rate, and enhance functional parameters like gait speed, functional capacity, muscle torque, and quality of life in stroke patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic stroke (36 participants).
effective_dosage: 30-minute sessions, three times a week, for 6 weeks (control: 0% inclination; experimental group 1: 5% inclination; experimental group 2: 10% inclination).
study_duration: 6 weeks, with follow-ups at 1 month and 1 year post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of targeted drugs (riociguat, macitentan, and subcutaneous treprostinil) in improving exercise capacity, measured by 6-minute walking distance, in patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).
results_summary: The study found that riociguat, macitentan, and subcutaneous treprostinil improved the 6-minute walking distance in CTEPH patients, as demonstrated by randomized control trials. However, 23% of patients still experienced persistent pulmonary hypertension after balloon pulmonary angioplasty (BPA).
population_specificity: Patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), particularly those inoperable or with persistent/recurrent CTEPH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of upper limb exercises and breathing exercises on six-minute walking distance in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
results_summary: Both upper limb and breathing exercises significantly increased walking distance compared to the control group, with upper limb exercises showing greater effectiveness than breathing exercises. The control group showed no significant change in walking distance.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease from an outpatient lung clinic in Iran.
effective_dosage: Upper limb exercises thrice weekly for one month; breathing exercises four times daily for one month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a transitional care intervention, including a tailored home exercise program and physical activity promotion, on physical activity and functional performance in cognitively impaired patients recovering from hip or pelvic fractures.
results_summary: The study evaluated a multifactorial intervention involving progressive home exercises and physical activity promotion, measuring outcomes like daily walking duration and functional performance. Results were assessed at baseline, post-intervention (4 months), and follow-up (7 months), but specific findings on efficacy were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65+ with mild to moderate cognitive impairment (MMSE 17-26) recovering from hip or pelvic fractures.
effective_dosage: Two home visits per week for exercise and activity promotion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of intracoronal bleaching (using a "walking bleach" technique) on IL-1β and RANK-L levels in periodontal tissues over six months.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in IL-1β and RANK-L levels post-bleaching, persisting for six months, with strong correlation between both biomarkers across all time points.
population_specificity: Fifty volunteers with nonvital teeth requiring bleaching.
effective_dosage: 35% hydrogen peroxide (G1) or 37% carbamide peroxide (G2), applied over four sessions.
study_duration: Six months (follow-up at one week, one month, and six months post-treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining plant sterols with 30 minutes of daily walking reduces postprandial triacylglycerol (TAG) concentrations in Chinese men with elevated BMI.
results_summary: The study found that combining plant sterols with daily walking significantly reduced postprandial TAG concentrations by 12-32% compared to control conditions, with the greatest reduction observed in the combined intervention (PS-W).
population_specificity: Chinese men aged 25 ± 3 years with elevated BMI (≥ 23.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether strength, agility, plyometric, and secondary prevention (SAPP) training with or without perturbation training (SAPP + PERT) improved gait mechanics and movement symmetry in women after ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: Neither SAPP nor SAPP + PERT training improved walking mechanics, with asymmetrical movement patterns persisting up to 1 year post-training but resolving by 2 years post-operatively. No meaningful differences were found between the two training groups.
population_specificity: Female athletes 3-9 months after primary ACL reconstruction.
study_duration: Training duration not explicitly stated; follow-up assessments occurred at Pre-training, Post-training, 1 year, and 2 years post-operatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether improvements in physical activity (PA) or physical performance (measured by a 2-km walking test) positively impact the quality of life (QoL) of breast cancer patients.
results_summary: Participants who increased their PA or improved their 2-km walking test performance showed significant improvements in global health, physical and social functioning, role functioning, fatigue, body image, and future perspectives. No significant differences were found between groups.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients post-adjuvant treatments (n=444).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-week structured exercise program (EXCAP) improved anxiety, mood, and well-being in older cancer patients during chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found statistically and clinically significant improvements in anxiety (STAI), mood (POMS), and social and emotional well-being among participants in the EXCAP group, particularly those with worse baseline symptoms.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 60+ years) undergoing chemotherapy, predominantly with breast cancer (77%).
effective_dosage: Home-based, low- to moderate-intensity progressive walking and resistance training program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association of motoric cognitive risk syndrome (MCR), which combines slow walking speed with subjective cognitive impairment, with incident cognitive impairment, cognitive performance, and brain structures.
results_summary: MCR was significantly associated with incident cognitive impairment (HR = 1.70) and dementia (HR = 2.50), as well as low grey matter volume in the premotor and prefrontal cortex and lacunar lesions in the frontal lobe. No significant association was found with white matter abnormalities.
population_specificity: Individuals with motoric cognitive risk syndrome (MCR), a pre-dementia stage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of core stabilization exercises (not Walking) on pulmonary function, respiratory muscle strength, and functional capacity in adolescents with substance use disorder.
results_summary: The study found that core stabilization exercises significantly improved maximal inspiratory pressure, pulmonary function, and functional capacity in adolescents with SUD. No results related to Walking were reported.
population_specificity: Adolescent male patients with substance use disorder (mean age ~16.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of facility-based supervised exercise training versus home-based telerehabilitation for improving walking performance in people with MS who have walking dysfunction and mobility disability.
results_summary: The study will evaluate walking speed as the primary outcome, along with secondary outcomes like walking endurance, disability status, and patient-reported measures of physical activity, walking impairment, fatigue, and quality of life. The intervention follows evidence-based guidelines, with the main difference being the delivery setting and coaching approach.
population_specificity: Physically inactive, cognitively intact individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) who have walking dysfunction and mobility disability (N = 500).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program details include individualized prescription but no exact dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bilateral custom-made ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) combined with fitted walking shoes could reduce falls in older adults compared to fitted walking shoes alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in fall reduction between the AFO group and the control group, though the AFO group showed significant reductions in falls compared to their baseline. The results suggest AFOs may help but require further investigation with larger samples.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65+ with concern about or at risk for falling (n=44).
effective_dosage: Daily use of bilateral custom-made AFOs and fitted walking shoes (intervention group) or fitted walking shoes alone (control group).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of rituximab (RTX) in patients with interstitial lung disease (ILD) related to connective tissue diseases (CTD), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that RTX stabilized or improved pulmonary function in CTD-ILD patients, particularly those with non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP), but did not assess Walking.
population_specificity: Patients with interstitial lung disease related to connective tissue diseases (CTD-ILD).
study_duration: Median RTX treatment duration was 3 years (IQR 1-6).

study_goal: To determine the effect of a tele-rehabilitation (TR) program, including breathing and callisthenic exercises, on glucose control, exercise capacity, physical fitness, muscle strength, and psychosocial status in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The TR group showed significant improvements in HbA1c levels, 6-minute walking distance, physical fitness subparameters, muscle strength, and depression levels, while the control group showed no significant improvements. The study concluded that TR interventions are safe and effective for type 2 DM management.
population_specificity: 50 participants with type 2 diabetes mellitus, mean age ~52-53 years.
effective_dosage: Breathing and callisthenic exercises, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention to increase walking during the commute to work among working adults.
results_summary: The intervention showed no evidence of an effect on moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) or overall physical activity at 12-month follow-up. The study concluded that focusing solely on individual behavior change was insufficient to alter travel behavior.
population_specificity: Working adults from 87 workplaces in south-west England and south Wales, primarily those living more than two kilometers from work and commuting by car.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of beraprost on pulmonary hypertension due to left ventricular systolic dysfunction (PH-HFrEF), including its impact on cardiopulmonary hemodynamics and exercise capacity.
results_summary: Beraprost significantly reduced systolic pulmonary artery pressure and improved left ventricular ejection fraction and six-minute walking distance over a 12-month period, with no severe adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with PH-HFrEF confirmed by echocardiography and right cardiac catheterization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different inspiratory muscle training (IMT) protocols combined with pulmonary rehabilitation on exercise capacity, inspiratory muscle function, and quality of life in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study compared three IMT protocols (no load, linear load, and isocapnic voluntary hyperpnea) alongside pulmonary rehabilitation, assessing outcomes like functional capacity (via walking tests), respiratory muscle strength, and quality of life, but final results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: 5 days a week (3 supervised) for 10 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of dual-task training (combining walking with cognitive tasks) compared to conventional occupational therapy for improving attention, executive function, and motor function in stroke patients.
results_summary: The dual-task group showed significantly greater improvements in auditory attention, memory span, executive function, and balance compared to the occupational therapy group, as measured by the Digit Span Test, Stroop Color and Word test, and Berg Balance Scale.
population_specificity: 30 stroke patients (15 in the dual-task group, 15 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 3 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a community walking program (GO-OUT) increased outdoor walking activity more effectively than a workshop with weekly reminders in older adults with difficulty walking outdoors.
results_summary: The study is designed to measure changes in outdoor walking time and secondary outcomes like physical activity, mobility, and quality of life, but results are not yet available (Pre-results).
population_specificity: Older adults with difficulty walking outdoors in four urban Canadian communities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of virtual reality-based therapy on postural stability and gross motor function (including walking) in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in gross motor function dimensions related to standing (D) and walking/running/jumping (E), with clinically meaningful gains (10.8% and 14.0%, respectively). The control group showed no improvements.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (GMFCS I-II) attending conventional physical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative short-term aggressive amino acid administration (including HMB, l-glutamine, and l-arginine) supports postoperative recovery of physical function and prevents complications in elderly patients undergoing cardiac surgery.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results regarding the effects of the intervention on walking or other outcomes are yet available.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (≥65 years) undergoing cardiac surgery.
effective_dosage: Amino acid supplement with HMB 1200mg, l-glutamine 7000mg, and l-arginine 7000mg once or twice daily depending on renal dysfunction.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of exercise and MFGM supplementation on walking ability and parameters in elderly Japanese women with declined walking ability.
results_summary: Exercise interventions, alone or combined with nutrition, improved walking speed, stride, and foot progression angle. MFGM supplementation did not show augmented effects when combined with exercise.
population_specificity: Elderly community-dwelling Japanese women over 79 years old with declined walking ability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validity and reliability of various vestibular system screening tests, including those involving walking, for clinical and epidemiological use.
results_summary: The abstract reviews multiple vestibular tests, including tandem walking, but does not provide specific results regarding walking's effectiveness or outcomes. It highlights the lack of a standardized, evidence-based screening battery for clinical use.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of vestibular tests)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of aerobic exercise training, including brisk walking, on the intestinal microbiota composition and physical fitness in healthy elderly women.
results_summary: The study found that both trunk muscle training and aerobic exercise (including brisk walking) improved trunk muscle strength and cardiorespiratory fitness, as measured by the K-W test and 6MWT. The relative abundance of intestinal microbiota was also assessed, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Sedentary women aged 65 years and older.
effective_dosage: Brisk walking at an intensity of ≥ 3 METs (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of the implanted ActiGait system on gait kinematics and spatiotemporal parameters in patients with drop foot over a 1-year follow-up period.
results_summary: The study found a significant improvement in maximum dorsal extension of the ankle at initial contact with ActiGait compared to no stimulation. While spatiotemporal parameters did not change much at convenient walking speed, patients walked faster with surface stimulation or ActiGait at their fastest possible speed, and they reported better health status at follow-up.
population_specificity: 10 patients with drop foot due to central nervous system lesions (8 completed follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of proprioceptive training on pain, stiffness, function, and functional test outcomes in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Proprioceptive training effectively reduced pain and improved functional daily activity in knee OA patients, but did not significantly impact stiffness or other mobility measures. The meta-analysis showed a moderate effect on pain relief (SMD = -0.56).
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (558 participants across 7 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and appraise the measurement properties of walking outcome measures for patients with neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: The study found that high-quality research on walking outcome measures for neurogenic claudication is lacking, but identified four measures with acceptable test-retest reliability and three with adequate responsiveness. The self-paced walking test and ODI walk item were recommended for clinical use pending further evidence.
population_specificity: Patients with neurogenic claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy and feasibility of a non-invasive pain management intervention (TENS) with and without patient education to improve physical activity in individuals with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The study will assess the efficacy of Active TENS and patient education on improving physical activity, with primary outcomes measured by absolute claudication distance and secondary outcomes including daily physical activity and patient-reported quality of life and pain metrics. Feasibility outcomes will evaluate recruitment, retention, and adherence rates.
population_specificity: Adults with PAD and IC (n=80).
effective_dosage: TENS device preset at 120 Hz, 200 μs, used daily at patient-determined intensity ("strong but comfortable").
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of supervised physical therapy (PT) versus unsupervised home exercise (HE) for improving symptoms, physical function, and walking ability in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: Supervised PT resulted in significantly greater improvements in symptom severity, physical function, walking distance, leg pain, and daily step count compared to unsupervised HE, with clinically meaningful differences observed across multiple outcome measures.
population_specificity: Patients with neurogenic claudication caused by LSS, confirmed by MRI.
effective_dosage: Supervised PT sessions twice a week (specific exercise details provided but no exact dosage quantified).

study_goal: The study does not address Walking; it focuses on smoking cessation interventions among Northern Plains American Indians.
results_summary: The study does not examine Walking; it reports on smoking abstinence rates and the effectiveness of pharmacologic support in a smoking cessation intervention.
population_specificity: Adult Northern Plains American Indians who smoke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a rehabilitation protocol involving balance exercises using Serious Game improves walking performance in patients who underwent knee resection and reconstruction for primary bone tumors.
results_summary: The study group showed improved walking speed (median difference of 0.22 m/s) and better postural control (median reduction of 4.5 mm/s in center mass speed) compared to the control group. The results were statistically significant (p = 0.022 and p = 0.005, respectively).
population_specificity: 30 patients undergoing modular prosthetic replacement following primary bone tumor resection.
effective_dosage: 25 minutes of training per session aimed at postural and proprioceptive control.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ongoing feedback (telephone calls, biofeedback via pedometer, and progressive goal setting) improved daily physical activity in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease during a 12-month unsupervised walking program.
results_summary: The study compared an intervention group receiving feedback to a usual care group without feedback, using the SenseWear® Pro3 Armband to measure physical activity. Results indicated that ongoing feedback may enhance physical activity maintenance, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: People with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (mean age 70 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of resistance training (RT) on walking ability in persons with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: RT significantly improved walking ability, including claudication onset and total walking distance on treadmills and flat ground, with high-intensity training yielding the greatest improvements. The study supports including high-intensity lower body RT in PAD treatment.
population_specificity: Persons with peripheral artery disease (mean age 67.1±3.8 years).
effective_dosage: Training ranged from low to high intensity, 2-7 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cycle ergometer training and resistance training enhance standard care for improving walking ability, lower limb strength, cardiovascular endurance, and quality of life in patients with intensive care unit-acquired weakness.
results_summary: Ergometer and resistance training improved lower limb strength, walking ability, and cardiorespiratory fitness more effectively than standard care alone, with ergometer training potentially being superior to resistance training.
population_specificity: Patients with severe to moderate walking disability during inpatient neurological rehabilitation for intensive care-acquired weakness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate step length asymmetry and its links to gait efficiency, fatigue, and physical function in individuals post-total hip replacement (THR), as well as investigate associations with mechanical energy exchange.
results_summary: The study found that step length symmetry was significantly different from zero and associated with better physical function (6MWT). Better mechanical energy exchange was linked to more fatigue, but not directly to step length symmetry or physical function. Improved physical function correlated with less fatigue.
population_specificity: 18 participants (6 males, 12 females) 1-5 years post-THR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of action observation therapy on improving walking ability, gait performance, and other motor functions in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that action observation therapy had a moderate to large effect on walking outcomes (Hedge's g = 0.779) and a large effect on gait velocity (Hedge's g = 0.990), indicating significant improvements in these areas for stroke patients.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (acute/subacute and chronic phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a high DHA multi-nutrient supplement and exercise on habitual walking speed, gait variables, cognitive function, and quality of life in older adults.
results_summary: The study suggests that omega-3 fatty acids, B vitamins, vitamin E, phosphatidylserine, and Ginkgo Biloba may help preserve mobility and cognitive function in older adults, with potential positive interactions between exercise and omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: Non-frail or pre-frail females aged ≥60 years.
study_duration: 24 weeks for dietary supplementation, with the final 12 weeks including exercise intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the corrective response of individuals with cerebellar ataxia to unexpected gait perturbations and the effectiveness of perturbation-based training in improving their dynamic stability during balance recovery and steady walking.
results_summary: Individuals with cerebellar ataxia retained a wider base of support during corrective responses and steady gait, and improved their anterior-posterior margin of stability during steady walking after training, but did not benefit from training in managing sudden perturbations.
population_specificity: Ten participants with cerebellar ataxia and eight age-matched healthy adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical- and cost-effectiveness of ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) and functional electrical stimulation (FES) for improving walking performance in people with Multiple Sclerosis experiencing foot drop.
results_summary: The study found that AFOs and FES had comparable effects on walking performance and patient-reported outcomes, but high dropout rates introduced uncertainty in the results.
population_specificity: Eighty-five treatment-naïve people with Multiple Sclerosis and persistent foot drop (>three months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of botulinum toxin A (BoNT) on gait mechanics, specifically spatiotemporal, kinematic, kinetic, and electromyographic measures, in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that BoNT injections improved various gait measures, including dorsiflexion, propulsive forces, and coordination, depending on the injection site, even when clinical measures like walking speed did not show significant improvement. However, most studies had a high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with spasticity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining BoNT-A with a four-week ankle isokinetic treatment improves function and spasticity more effectively than BoNT-A alone in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that BoNT-A combined with isokinetic treatment may have a positive effect on function and spasticity compared to BoNT-A alone, and it investigated the validity of using an isokinetic dynamometer for measuring stretch reflex and residual strength.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=25)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if robotic gait training (RGT) improves walking speed, endurance, balance, and muscle oxygenation in children with hemiparetic cerebral palsy (hCP) compared to standard physiotherapy.
results_summary: RGT improved walking speed, endurance, balance, and peripheral oxygenation in hCP children, with sustained benefits at 3-month follow-up, while standard physiotherapy showed temporary improvements.
population_specificity: 24 children with hemiparetic cerebral palsy (hCP) who could walk.
effective_dosage: RGT program three times a week alongside standard physiotherapy (three days a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a French version of the PLUS-M 12-item Short-Form questionnaire and assess its psychometric properties for evaluating lower limb amputees' perceived walking capacity.
results_summary: The French version demonstrated good to excellent psychometric properties, with validity, internal consistency, and reliability ranging from low to excellent (r=0.43 to 0.84). The results were comparable to the original version, supporting its use in clinical and research settings.
population_specificity: 52 lower limb amputees (age 53±16, 40 males, varying amputation types and causes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify determinants of COPD Assessment Test (CAT) scores, evaluate symptom load, and investigate discrepancies between CAT and mMRC scores in classifying COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that CAT scores were significantly associated with factors like depression, exacerbation history, 6-minute walking distance, and FEV1(%), with notable variations across countries. It also revealed discrepancies in patient classification when using CAT versus mMRC scores.
population_specificity: COPD patients (69.2% men, mean FEV1% predicted 52.5%) from 11 Central and Eastern European countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a caregiver-mediated exercise program with e-health support (CARE4STROKE) could improve functional outcomes and facilitate early discharge in stroke patients by increasing task-specific training intensity.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in primary outcomes (mobility and length of stay) but noted favorable effects on secondary outcomes, such as reduced anxiety in patients and depression in caregivers. The intervention did not significantly enhance functional outcomes like walking ability or balance.
population_specificity: Stroke patients and their caregivers during inpatient rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: 150 minutes per week of additional caregiver-mediated exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pedometers, as a motivational tool, could improve functional mobility and related outcomes in inpatient rehabilitation patients.
results_summary: The study found that pedometers without step targets did not improve functional mobility but may have increased daily upright time in the studied population.
population_specificity: 78 participants with reduced mobility in a subacute hospital rehabilitation unit in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of walking and other exercise interventions on sleep quality in breast cancer patients during or after treatment.
results_summary: Walking, as part of physical exercise interventions, improved subjective sleep scores (SMD -0.32) and specific sleep quality subscales, but no significant effects were found on objective sleep measures.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer during or after treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the performance of the LIFESTREAM balloon-expandable covered stent for treating iliac artery atherosclerotic lesions, focusing on safety, efficacy, and quality of life improvements, including walking ability.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking ability, as measured by the Walking Impairment Questionnaire (WIQ), with a mean change in total score of 32.1 ± 26.84 from baseline to 9 months. Additionally, 90.5% of patients showed clinical improvement in at least one Rutherford category.
population_specificity: 155 patients with iliac artery atherosclerotic lesions treated at 17 centers in the United States, Europe, and New Zealand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oligonol supplementation on immune cell counts and inflammatory markers in healthy males after heat loading.
results_summary: Oligonol intake reduced elevations in IL-1β and IL-6 post-heating and increased leukocyte, lymphocyte, T cell, B cell, and NK cell counts compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 19 healthy male volunteers

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of early oral nutritional supplements versus traditional treatment with water or lemonade in the PACU after colon surgery.
results_summary: Patients receiving early nutritional supplements had higher energy and protein intake by the second postoperative day compared to those given water or lemonade, but no significant differences were observed in nausea, vomiting, pain, PACU stay, or nasogastric tube need.
population_specificity: Patients admitted for elective colon surgery.
study_duration: Intervention administered in the PACU (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Oligonol supplementation on sudomotor activity during heat load in humans.
results_summary: Oligonol attenuated increases in tympanic and skin temperatures after heat load and showed a decreasing trend in sweat rate, volume, active sweat gland density, and sweat gland output compared to placebo. The mean active sweat gland density was significantly higher in the Oligonol group at multiple time points.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: One week per study arm with a 2-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate an LC-MS/MS method for the simultaneous determination of 15 water-soluble vitamins in beverages and dietary supplements.
results_summary: The method successfully separated and identified 15 water-soluble vitamins using a multi-mode ODS column without ion pair reagents, verified by analysis of a NIST Standard Reference Material. It was found suitable for quality control and nutrition labeling of vitamin-enriched products.
population_specificity: Commercial beverages and dietary supplements (no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and test the acceptability of locally available ready-to-use supplementary food (RUSF) for improving micronutrient status and growth in children.
results_summary: Two RUSFs (rice-lentil and chickpea-based) were developed and found to be more accepted by children and mothers compared to the cereal-based Pushti packet, with significant differences in consumption favoring the chickpea-based RUSF.
population_specificity: 90 children aged 6-18 months in a slum of Dhaka city, Bangladesh.
effective_dosage: 50 g of RUSF or Pushti packet offered per feeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a dental water jet rinse mixed with chlorhexidine gel could enhance the nonsurgical treatment of peri-implantitis.
results_summary: The study found that the water jet with chlorhexidine gel group showed greater reductions in probing depth and bleeding on probing sites compared to the control group, though no significant bone level changes were observed.
population_specificity: 40 patients with peri-implantitis (39 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Twice daily use of the water jet device containing chlorhexidine gel.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the impact of impaired water and ion secretion due to cystic fibrosis on digestive and absorptive functions.
results_summary: The study found that cystic fibrosis disrupts Cl(-) secretion, leading to dehydration of secretions, pH alterations, and obstruction of lumens, which impair digestion and absorption, particularly of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy is used but faces challenges due to lipase susceptibility to inactivation and reduced bile availability.
population_specificity: Individuals with cystic fibrosis affecting the digestive tract and associated organs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Nutri-jelly, a water-releasing food gel, could improve health-related quality of life and reduce nasogastric tube feeding use in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that Nutri-jelly supplementation significantly improved overall HRQOL scores and reduced tube feeding use (13.5% vs. 48.6% in controls), particularly alleviating swallowing difficulty and eating problems.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients undergoing definitive radiotherapy (25-35 fractions, 5,000-7,000 cGy).
study_duration: Throughout radiotherapy (exact duration not specified, but implied to cover 25-35 fractions).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to characterize the toxicological properties of gasoline and related substances, not Water.
results_summary: The abstract discusses hazard characterization data for gasoline and refinery streams but does not mention Water or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focuses on gasoline, not Water).

study_goal: The study does not address Water; it focuses on evaluating the effects of yellow pea fibre supplementation on weight loss and gut microbiota in overweight and obese adults.
results_summary: The study does not provide results related to Water.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (BMI = 25-38)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sulphurous mineral water (SMW) supplementation could mitigate exercise-induced muscle damage, improve antioxidant activity, and influence peripheral blood markers in well-trained athletes.
results_summary: SMW supplementation increased total thiols and catalase activity, reduced creatine phosphokinase levels, and improved blood cell markers compared to placebo, suggesting protective effects against exercise-induced muscle damage.
population_specificity: Thirty well-trained male triathletes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare zinc absorption from zinc citrate, zinc gluconate, and zinc oxide supplements in healthy adults to assess their potential for preventing zinc deficiency and treating diarrhea.
results_summary: Zinc citrate and zinc gluconate showed similar absorption rates (~61%), while zinc oxide had significantly lower absorption (~50%). Some individuals had minimal absorption from zinc oxide.
population_specificity: 15 healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular design of lipopeptide gelators and their ability to harden various liquids, including water, for creating supramolecular gel templates.
results_summary: The study found that lipopeptide amphiphiles can effectively harden water and other liquids, forming robust gels capable of incorporating various elements for material preparation. The review also provided insights into the molecular design of these gelators.
population_specificity: Not specified (review paper)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of water extracts of Graptopetalum paraguayense (WGP) on blood pressure, blood glucose, lipid profiles, and antioxidant enzyme activities in subjects with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: WGP supplementation significantly reduced fasting glucose, systolic blood pressure, and LDL-C levels while increasing HDL-C levels and antioxidant enzyme activities (CAT and SOD). Blood pressure, glucose, and lipid profiles were correlated with improved antioxidant enzyme activities.
population_specificity: Subjects with metabolic syndrome (n = 54 initially, n = 42 completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing halva with defatted sesame seed coats and date fibre concentrate could improve its nutritional and organoleptic qualities, particularly in terms of water and fat retention.
results_summary: The study found that adding both fibres with an emulsifier improved emulsion stability, increased halva hardness, and enhanced sensory qualities, while also providing nutritional benefits like polyphenol antioxidants and laxative effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general consumers, but not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between zinc deficiency and atopic dermatitis (AD) in children, and the efficacy of oral zinc supplementation in improving AD symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that children with AD had significantly lower hair zinc levels compared to controls. After 8 weeks of zinc supplementation, AD patients showed significant improvements in eczema severity, skin barrier function (TEWL), and subjective symptoms like pruritus and sleep disturbance compared to the non-supplemented group.
population_specificity: 58 children with atopic dermatitis (AD) and 43 controls, aged 2-14 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pre-treatment with vitamin D3 affects biomarkers of early acute lung injury in patients undergoing elective transthoracic oesophagectomy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding the effects of vitamin D3 on lung injury biomarkers, as it describes the study design and objectives rather than outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective transthoracic oesophagectomy in three UK centres.
effective_dosage: 300,000 IU (7.5 mg) cholecalciferol in oily solution administered as a single oral dose seven days pre-operatively.
study_duration: Single dose administered seven days before surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the multidrug resistance (MDR) reversal effects of Rabdosia rubescens extracts, including the aqueous fraction (AF), on human breast cancer cells (MCF-7/Adr).
results_summary: The aqueous fraction (AF) showed little effect on intracellular accumulation of adriamycin or Rh123 in MCF-7/Adr cells, indicating minimal efficacy in reversing MDR.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cell line MCF-7/Adr (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified for the aqueous fraction (AF).
study_duration: 48 hours for CF and EAF treatments (AF duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review historical herbal treatments for osteoporosis, focusing on their properties, flavors, meridian attributions, and compatibility.
results_summary: The study identified 389 prescriptions involving 238 herbal drugs, with warm and plain properties, sweet and bitter flavors, and Kidney and Liver meridian attributions being most common. The primary treatment approach involved Kidney, Liver, and Spleen supplementation, complemented by diuresis and stasis dissolution.
population_specificity: Not specified (historical prescriptions from "Chinese Medical Classics").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of carbohydrate (CHO) supplementation, alone or with protein, on postexercise rehydration and recovery from muscle damage compared to water.
results_summary: The study found that adding CHO to a rehydration solution improved fluid restoration compared to water, and combining CHO with protein further enhanced recovery from muscle damage and soreness.
population_specificity: Active individuals, particularly those engaging in novel or eccentric exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunological effects of an aqueous extract of Vernonia amygdalina leaves and immunace(®) on HIV-infected patients.
results_summary: The study found that the aqueous extract of V. amygdalina and immunace(®) increased CD4 counts in HIV-infected patients, with the greatest increase observed in those taking both. Skin rashes also improved across all groups.
population_specificity: HIV-infected patients on highly active antiretroviral therapy.
effective_dosage: Two handfuls of fresh leaves soaked in 200 mL water, squeezed into a mixture (exact dosage frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers investigated whether Oligonol supplementation could mitigate increases in body temperature and inflammatory markers (PGE2 and COX-2) under heat stress conditions.
results_summary: Oligonol significantly prevented elevation in tympanic and mean body temperatures and reduced serum levels of PGE2 and COX-2 compared to placebo, suggesting it may help regulate body temperature under heat stress.
population_specificity: 17 healthy human male volunteers (age 21.6±2.1 years).
effective_dosage: 100 mg Oligonol in a single dose before heat exposure.
study_duration: Acute intervention (measurements taken before, immediately after, and 60 min after heat exposure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of slum upgrading strategies, including water supply improvements, on health and socio-economic outcomes in urban slum dwellers in low- and middle-income countries.
results_summary: The study found that water supply interventions reduced diarrhoeal incidence and severity, as well as decreased water-related expenditures, though results were mixed for other outcomes. Supporting studies reinforced these findings but noted inconsistencies in other health and financial poverty indicators.
population_specificity: Urban slum dwellers in low- and middle-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether deuterium-depleted drinking water (DDW) could serve as a nontoxic adjuvant therapy to improve survival outcomes in lung cancer patients.
results_summary: DDW consumption was associated with significantly longer median survival times (25.9 months in males, 74.1 months in females) and attenuated DMBA-induced expression of cancer-related genes (Bcl2, Kras, Myc) in mice. Cumulative 5-year survival probabilities were higher in females (52%) and patients with brain metastasis (33%).
population_specificity: 129 patients with small cell and nonsmall cell lung cancers, including those with brain metastasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review nutritional deficiencies, particularly vitamins and trace elements, in Crohn's Disease patients and explore therapeutic perspectives, including supplementation.
results_summary: The study highlights frequent nutritional deficiencies in Crohn's Disease patients, both during active disease and remission, and suggests that specific supplementation of vitamins and nutrients may be beneficial. It also notes the impact of biological therapy on nutritional status.
population_specificity: Adult patients with Crohn's Disease (a type of inflammatory bowel disease).

study_goal: The researchers examined the use of human albumin (HA) in burn treatment, focusing on its role in acute resuscitation and chronic supplementation to correct hypoalbuminemia.
results_summary: HA administration during acute burn resuscitation reduces nonburn tissue edema and fluid requirements but does not prevent burn wound edema and may increase lung water accumulation. Chronic HA supplementation post-resuscitation is costly with unclear clinical benefits.
population_specificity: Burn patients (acute and chronic phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydrogen-rich water could effectively treat symptoms of interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome (IC/PBS).
results_summary: The study found that hydrogen-rich water did not significantly improve symptoms compared to placebo, though it showed notable pain reduction in a small subset (11%) of patients. Both groups experienced significant reductions in bladder pain scores.
population_specificity: Patients with IC/PBS (29 women, 1 man, mean age 64.0 ± 14.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the causes, implications, and treatment approaches for hyponatremia, particularly in the elderly population.
results_summary: The study highlights the multifactorial nature of hyponatremia in the elderly, its impact on cognitive function and bone health, and reviews various treatment options, including water restriction, medications, and vasopressin antagonists, noting their efficacy and limitations.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, particularly those prone to hyponatremia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the associations between maternal total body water (TBW) and changes in TBW with placental and birth weights in a malnourished population.
results_summary: Higher maternal TBW at ~10 weeks gestation and gains in TBW from 20-32 weeks were positively associated with placental weight and birth weight. TBW changes from 10-20 weeks were also positively linked to placental weight.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in a malnourished population (subsample of 350 women from a larger trial).
study_duration: Measurements taken at ~10, ~20, and ~32 weeks of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association and contribution of hyperhomocysteinemia (HHcy) to abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) formation, using homocysteine (Hcy) supplementation in drinking water as part of their methodology.
results_summary: The study found that HHcy significantly increased the incidence of AAA and aortic dissection in mice, with marked aortic adventitial inflammation and activation of adventitial fibroblasts via NADPH oxidase 4. Folic acid supplementation reduced HHcy-aggravated AAA formation.
population_specificity: Male apolipoprotein E-deficient mice.
effective_dosage: Hcy supplement (1.8 g/L) in drinking water; folic acid supplement (0.071 μg/g per day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein-energy supplementation, which included 400mL of water daily, could prevent functional decline in frail older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group, which received the supplement (including water), showed improvements in physical functioning and gait speed compared to controls, though no direct effects of water alone were isolated.
population_specificity: Frail older adults with low socioeconomic status (usual gait speed <0.6 m/second; Mini Nutritional Assessment <24).
