effective_dosage: 400mL of water daily (as part of a 400 kcal liquid formula).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to formulate soybean lecithin nanoparticles in a solvent-free aqueous system and assess their physical and chemical stability over a 3-month storage period at different temperatures.
results_summary: The study found that lecithin nanoparticles remained physically and chemically stable at 4°C for 3 months, with minimal changes in particle size and peroxide levels. At 25°C, stability was maintained for 60 days before degradation and particle size increase occurred.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sodium citrate supplementation during recovery from rapid body mass loss on physiological functions, affective state, and performance in trained wrestlers.
results_summary: Sodium citrate increased blood buffering capacity, plasma volume, and body mass regain during recovery but did not improve performance or affect mood. Water intake was ad libitum, and body mass gain was associated with water retention in the sodium citrate group.
population_specificity: Trained wrestlers (N=16)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of supplementary water intake during the school day on cognitive performance and subjective states like fatigue or vigor in children living in a hot climate.
results_summary: The study found that a significant proportion of children were mildly dehydrated at the start of the school day. Drinking supplementary water improved short-term memory (auditory number span) but showed mixed results in verbal analogy tasks.
population_specificity: 168 children aged 9-11 years living in a hot climate (South Italy, Sardinia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of folate in breast cancer risk and develop interventions for high-risk women.
results_summary: The abstract discusses folate's dual effects on carcinogenesis but does not report specific findings about water.
population_specificity: High-risk women (e.g., those with benign breast disease, strong family history, or BRCA mutations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether improved water transport and storage containers could enhance water quality and health outcomes in poor rural households.
results_summary: The study found that improved household water infrastructure significantly improved water quality and health outcomes, with an 88% usage rate after 7 months, suggesting sustainable adoption. The intervention was cost-effective, costing only 5% of providing improved public water supply.
population_specificity: Poor rural households in an environment with good point-of-source water quality but widespread recontamination.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the long-term treatment efficacy and tolerability of fluid restriction and urea in managing nephrogenic syndrome of inappropriate antidiuresis (NSIAD).
results_summary: The study found that long-term fluid restriction and low-dose urea were effective and well-tolerated in managing NSIAD, with episodic urea intake sufficient for some patients. AVPR2 antagonists showed no efficacy, while NaCl supplementation had varying results.
population_specificity: Male patients with NSIAD (3 cases reported) and a review of 16 hyponatremic patients from literature.
effective_dosage: Low doses of urea (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the role of L-arginine in metabolic pathways, including its effects on fatty acid oxidation to CO2 and water, rather than directly studying water itself.
results_summary: The study found that L-arginine stimulates lipolysis and fatty acid oxidation to CO2 and water, enhances mitochondrial biogenesis, and reduces white adipose tissue in various models, but did not directly assess water's effects.
population_specificity: Zucker diabetic fatty rats, diet-induced obese rats, growing-finishing pigs, and obese patients with type II diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine associations between maternal nutritional status in early pregnancy and extracellular water (ECW), total body water (TBW), and plasma volume changes across pregnancy.
results_summary: Higher early pregnancy BMI was associated with higher ECW and TBW but lower gains in these measures from 10 to 20 weeks. BMI was also positively linked to plasma volume expansion from 20 to 32 weeks. Shorter and thinner women had lower ECW, TBW, and plasma volume expansion, potentially increasing fetal growth restriction risk.
population_specificity: 377 pregnant women in a cluster-randomized trial of micronutrient supplementation.
study_duration: Measurements taken at ~10, 20, and 32 weeks of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a purified, standard water-soluble fraction from Phlebodium decamanum could reduce oxidative stress and inflammation induced by strenuous exercise.
results_summary: The study found that oral supplementation of P. decumanum effectively reduced oxidative stress (decreased 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine and isoprostanes, increased antioxidant enzyme activities) and inflammation (decreased TNF-α, increased sTNF-RII, maintained IL-6 and IL-1ra levels).
population_specificity: Professional and amateur athletes performing strenuous exercise (mountain run and ultra-endurance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a high-energy protein supplement (HEPS) on nutritional status, including total body water (TBW), fat-free mass (FFM), and fat mass (FM), in HIV-infected females initiating ARV treatment.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Water's effects, as the study is described as a protocol for future data collection.
population_specificity: HIV-infected females commencing ARV treatment at two clinics in Lusaka, Zambia.
study_duration: 12 months (with data collection at baseline, 4, 8, and 12 months)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of natural S-equol supplementation on skin aging in equol-nonproducing Japanese postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that S-equol supplementation (10 mg and 30 mg/day) significantly reduced crow's-feet wrinkle area and depth compared to placebo, with no significant effects on other skin parameters or adverse events in hormone status or gynecological examinations.
population_specificity: Equol-nonproducing Japanese postmenopausal women (n=101).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of chronic daily MSM supplementation (prepared in water) on oxidative stress markers following acute exercise in untrained healthy young men.
results_summary: The study found that MSM supplementation in water maintained lower levels of oxidative stress markers (PC, MDA, GSSG) post-exercise compared to placebo (water alone). The MSM group also showed higher plasma GSH levels and GSH/GSSG ratios, indicating improved antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: Untrained healthy young men (n=18).
effective_dosage: MSM was prepared in water at 50 mg/kg body weight daily.

study_goal: The study aimed to compare exercise intensity and energy expenditure during trail walking in older adults and assess the effects of BCAA and arginine supplementation on muscle damage and performance.
results_summary: The study found that trail walking required high-intensity effort for older adults, but BCAA and arginine supplementation had only modest effects on performance and muscle damage markers. Water intake was measured but not analyzed for safety or efficacy.
population_specificity: Older adults (~63 years, mixed gender)

study_goal: The study aimed to determine whether Panax ginseng extract mixed with water influenced exercise-induced muscle damage and inflammation responses, not specifically to evaluate water's effects.
results_summary: The study did not report specific findings about water's effects, as it primarily focused on the impact of Panax ginseng extract.
population_specificity: 18 male college students
effective_dosage: 200 ml of water mixed with Panax ginseng extract or Agastachis Herba, three times/day
study_duration: 11 days (7 days pre-exercise and 4 days post-exercise)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to clarify the differences between prescription and dietary supplement niacin products, focusing on their regulatory standards and clinical efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that prescription niacin products demonstrated safety and efficacy in clinical trials, while dietary supplement niacin products, particularly "no-flush" or "flush-free" variants, lacked beneficial lipid-modifying effects.
population_specificity: Patients with mixed dyslipidemia (high LDL-C, elevated TGs, and low HDL-C).

study_goal: The study does not focus on evaluating the safety, efficacy, or quality of water; it examines the effectiveness of Alpha-1-adrenergic receptor antagonists as an adjunctive therapy after ESWL for renal stones.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to water's effects, as its primary focus was on the efficacy of Alfuzosin in improving stone expulsion rates post-ESWL.
population_specificity: Patients with renal stones (0.5-1.5 cm in size) undergoing ESWL.
effective_dosage: Patients were instructed to drink a minimum of 2 liters of water daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute supplementation of Panax ginseng (PG) affected endurance running performance in heat-adapted recreational runners in a hot and humid environment, with water used to prevent dehydration.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in endurance running time, physiological markers (heart rate, temperature, oxygen uptake), or metabolic parameters (glucose, lactate, insulin, free fatty acids) between PG and placebo trials when water was administered during exercise.
population_specificity: Heat-adapted male recreational runners in Malaysia (n=9, age 25.4 ± 6.9 years).
effective_dosage: 3 ml/kg body weight of cool water every 20 minutes during exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential role of silicon in preventing oral aluminum absorption and retention in mammals, particularly its implications for Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study suggests that silicon might have a protective effect against aluminum absorption, potentially reducing chronic aluminum accumulation in the brain, which could be therapeutic for Alzheimer's disease. However, controversy remains about whether aluminum accumulation is a cause or consequence of Alzheimer's.
population_specificity: Mammals (specific human population not detailed).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the influence of calorie restriction (CR) on free-living physical activity levels among humans, not specifically related to Water.
results_summary: The study found that calorie restriction led to variable decreases in activity energy expenditure (AEE), which reduced the expected rate of weight loss. Accelerometry and recall methods did not consistently detect changes in activity categories.
population_specificity: Nonobese adults (BMI = 23.5-29.9 kg/m²) from three research centers.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on calorie restriction, not Water).
study_duration: 6 to 12 months, depending on the research center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a konjac glucomannan (KGM) supplement on precancerous markers of colon cancer in a low-fibre diet.
results_summary: The KGM supplement significantly reduced faecal β-glucuronidase activity and secondary bile acid levels, increased survival rates of Caco-2 cells, and reduced DNA damage. It also improved faecal microbial ecology by increasing bifidobacteria and lactobacilli levels.
population_specificity: Adult volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the relative bioavailability of zinc (Zn) when administered in two different dosing forms (aqueous ZnSO₄ solution and NutriSet Zn tablets) with plain water.
results_summary: The study found that the bioavailability of Zn from NutriSet tablets was only about half that of aqueous ZnSO₄, as measured by plasma Zn levels over time. This suggests that tablet forms may result in lower intestinal Zn uptake than anticipated.
population_specificity: 10 healthy male volunteers
effective_dosage: 30 mg Zn (as ZnSO₄ solution or 1.5 NutriSet Zn tablets) with 200 ml plain water
study_duration: Single-dose administration with blood collection up to 240 minutes post-ingestion

study_goal: The researchers evaluated the effect of protein supplementation enriched with branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) on nutritional and inflammatory markers in acutely ill elderly patients with catabolic status.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in weight, fat-free mass, nitrogen balance, or energy intake between supplemented and control groups. However, a significant decrease in inflammatory markers (orosomucoid and PINI) was observed in the supplemented group.
population_specificity: Thirty elderly patients with malnutrition and inflammatory processes (MNA < 24, albumin < 30 g/l, CRP ≥ 20 mg/l) in a geriatric hospital setting.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether water, as a control, had any effect on cardiovascular risk factors compared to freeze-dried strawberry supplementation in obese subjects with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of water consumption on blood pressure, serum glucose, triglycerides, HDL cholesterol, or waist circumference compared to the strawberry supplement group. Water served as a neutral control with no measurable impact on the studied parameters.
population_specificity: Obese subjects with metabolic syndrome (2 males and 25 females; BMI 37.5 ± 2.15 kg/m²; age 47.0 ± 3.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of low-dose creatine supplementation on body composition, muscle function, and body creatine retention.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in body composition or maximal strength, but creatine supplementation increased plasma creatine levels and improved resistance to muscle fatigue during high-intensity contractions.
population_specificity: Twenty healthy men and women (21 ± 2 years old).

study_goal: The study does not address Water; it focuses on the effects of growth hormone and testosterone on body composition and athletic performance.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to Water.
population_specificity: Recreationally trained athletes (63 men and 33 women) with a mean age of 27.9 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of creatine monohydrate supplementation on active range of movement (ROM) and its potential relationship with intracellular water changes.
results_summary: Short-term creatine monohydrate supplementation significantly reduced active ROM in shoulder extension, shoulder abduction, and ankle dorsiflexion, while also increasing body mass. The mechanism may involve asymmetrical muscle mass distribution around joints.
population_specificity: 40 male subjects (age 24±3.2 years)
effective_dosage: 25 g/day for 5 days, followed by 5 g/day for 3 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) ingestion could enhance intermittent-sprint performance in elite water polo players during a simulated match.
results_summary: NaHCO3 ingestion increased extracellular pH and bicarbonate levels but did not substantially improve mean sprint times compared to placebo (effect size = 0.09, p = .51). The study concluded that water polo players should not expect significant performance enhancement from NaHCO3 supplementation.
population_specificity: Twelve elite female players from the Australian National Women's Water Polo Squad (age 23.7 ± 3.0 yr, height 1.73 ± 0.05 m, body mass 75.7 ± 8.0 kg).
effective_dosage: 0.3 g/kg of NaHCO3 ingested 90 min before the match-simulation test.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with performance measured during a 59-min match-simulation test.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether human atrial natriuretic peptide (HANP) could improve extravascular lung water (EVLW) and pulmonary vascular permeability index (PVPI) in pulmonary edema patients without heart disease, using the PiCCO(TM) system for monitoring.
results_summary: HANP significantly improved EVLW and PVPI in patients with normal intrathoracic blood volume (ITBV) but showed no significant improvement in those with abnormal ITBV. Both groups' EVLW and PVPI correlated strongly with chest X-ray findings.
population_specificity: 10 pulmonary edema patients without heart disease, divided into normal ITBV (n=6) and abnormal ITBV (n=4) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-carbohydrate diet and glucose ingestion during exercise on fuel selection in men and women, including those taking oral contraceptives.
results_summary: The study found that glucose ingestion during exercise increased carbohydrate oxidation more in women than in men, primarily due to a smaller reduction in endogenous glucose oxidation. No significant differences were observed between women taking or not taking oral contraceptives.
population_specificity: Six men, six women not taking oral contraceptives, and six women taking oral contraceptives.
effective_dosage: 2 g/kg of glucose ingested during exercise.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of nutritional interventions, including multinutrient feeds and supplements, on older people recovering from hip fractures.
results_summary: The study found weak evidence for the effectiveness of protein and energy feeds, with no significant effects on mortality or complications in most trials. Some trials suggested potential benefits in reducing long-term medical complications with protein supplementation.
population_specificity: Older people aged over 65 years with hip fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of BCAA supplementation versus artificially flavored water (placebo) on muscle soreness and function recovery after intense eccentric exercise.
results_summary: The study found that artificially flavored water (placebo) did not significantly differ from BCAA supplementation in mitigating muscle function loss, but BCAA showed a modest reduction in muscle soreness at 48 and 72 hours post-exercise.
population_specificity: 24 non-weight-trained males
effective_dosage: Not specified for water (placebo group consumed artificially flavored water as needed)
study_duration: 3 days (supplements consumed before exercise and for 3 days post-exercise)

study_goal: The study does not assess the effects of water; it focuses on black tea's impact on uric acid and C-reactive protein levels in individuals susceptible to ischemic heart diseases.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to water's effects; it only describes outcomes associated with black tea consumption.
population_specificity: Humans susceptible to ischemic heart diseases
effective_dosage: Not applicable (water was used as a control, not studied)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of sodium alginate (not water) on gastric functions, satiation, appetite, and gut hormones in overweight or obese adults.
results_summary: The study found that 10 days of alginate treatment had no effect on gastric motor functions, satiation, appetite, or gut hormones compared to placebo. There was no difference in outcomes between obese and overweight participants.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults without psychiatric comorbidity or binge eating disorder (n=48).
effective_dosage: Three capsules per day (ingested 30 min before the main meal); six capsules ingested with water 30 min before tests on days 8-10.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the excretion pattern of nandrolone metabolites differs when 19-norandrostenedione is ingested with water versus a solid supplement.
results_summary: The study found that urine volume was higher when 19-norandrostenedione was ingested with water compared to an energy bar. Peak urinary 19-NA concentrations were lower and occurred earlier with water, suggesting faster absorption and/or increased diuresis.
population_specificity: 10 male and 9 female volunteers (mean age 26 ± 3 years).
effective_dosage: 500 mL of plain water with 10 µg of 19-norandrostenedione.

study_goal: The researchers were not attempting to determine anything about Water; the abstract focuses on neurological disorders linked to deficiencies of water-soluble B vitamins.
results_summary: The study does not address Water's effects; it reviews historical and clinical aspects of B vitamin deficiencies and their neurological impacts.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study does not focus on Water).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study does not focus on Water).
study_duration: Not applicable (study does not focus on Water).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a whey protein hydrolysate (WPI(HD)) in flavored water could accelerate recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage compared to plain flavored water or regular whey protein isolate (WPI).
results_summary: The study found that WPI(HD) in flavored water fully restored peak isometric torque by 6 hours post-exercise, while plain flavored water and regular WPI did not. Muscle soreness increased post-exercise but did not differ between groups, and no changes were observed in serum creatine kinase or plasma TNFalpha levels.
population_specificity: 28 sedentary males
effective_dosage: 25 g of WPI or WPI(HD) in 250 ml of flavored water, consumed once post-exercise
study_duration: Assessments were conducted up to 24 hours post-intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the NoMYB60 gene in flavonoid synthesis in watercress and its response to stress-related hormones.
results_summary: The study found that NoMYB60 expression was regulated by ABA, SA, and MeJA, and its silencing promoted flavonoid synthesis. Additionally, NoMYB60 interacts with NoBEH1/2, suggesting a role in flavonoid pathway regulation.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or plant-based study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antimicrobial, anti-hemolytic, antioxidant, and wound healing properties of watercress oil alone and when incorporated into Vaseline gel (OLG).
results_summary: OLG showed enhanced antimicrobial activity, anti-hemolytic effects, and wound healing properties compared to watercress oil alone, with larger inhibition zones, lower MIC/MBC values, and improved wound closure rates.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on microbial strains and wound healing assays).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations like 25%, 50%, and 75% MIC were used for anti-hemolytic testing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether watercress extract (WCE) could counteract hair loss and greying by modulating RSPO1 and DKK1 secretion in dermal papilla cells and improve hair growth in human trials.
results_summary: WCE significantly increased RSPO1 secretion and reduced DKK1 secretion in a dose-dependent manner, even with DHT present. In human hair follicles, WCE treatment led to 1.6-fold elongation compared to controls, and a clinical trial showed improved hair thickness and density with a 2% WCE lotion.
population_specificity: Human hair follicles from a female donor (ex vivo) and a male panel (clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the carotenoid biosynthesis pathway (CBP) genes in Watercress (Nasturtium officinale) and assess their tissue-specific expression and carotenoid content.
results_summary: The study identified 11 carotenoid pathway genes in Watercress, with tissue-specific expression patterns (highest in flowers and leaves). High-performance liquid chromatography revealed seven carotenoid compounds, with the highest total content in leaves, dominated by lutein, E-β-carotene, and 9-Z-β-carotene.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro/genomic study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the red to far-red light ratio affects gluconasturtiin (GNST) concentrations in watercress.
results_summary: Watercress given end-of-day (EOD) far-red (FR) pulses had the lowest GNST concentrations, while an EOD red (R) followed by FR pulse resulted in the highest GNST concentrations. The study suggests light conditions can influence GNST accumulation in watercress.
population_specificity: Watercress plants (Nasturtium officinale) under controlled light conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunoregulatory and anti-inflammatory effects of watercress on the human immune system, particularly during and after exercise.
results_summary: Watercress consumption led to a mild pro-inflammatory response initially, followed by a stronger anti-inflammatory downregulation of cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α) during recovery. The immune response was more pronounced after exercise compared to the control meal.
population_specificity: 19 healthy subjects (26.5 ± 4.3 years; 14 males, 5 females).
effective_dosage: Single dose of 85 g fresh watercress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different elicitors on the production of bioactive compounds (glucosinolates, flavonoids, polyphenols, etc.) and assess antioxidant and anti-melanin activities in watercress microshoot cultures.
results_summary: Elicitation increased glucosinolate and flavonoid production, with MeJA and NaSA showing the most significant effects. Antioxidant potential improved with MeJA treatment, and microshoot extracts demonstrated tyrosinase inhibition, indicating anti-melanin activity.
population_specificity: Watercress (Nasturtium officinale) microshoot cultures
effective_dosage: 100 μM NaSA, 50 μM NaSA, 100 μM MeJA, and other elicitors (ETH, YeE)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of hydroalcoholic watercress extract on inflammatory cytokines and protein carbonyl levels in chronic hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in protein carbonyl levels in the intervention group, indicating reduced protein oxidation. While reductions in hs-CRP and IL-6 were observed in the intervention group, these changes were not statistically significant compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Chronic hemodialysis patients (n=45).
effective_dosage: 500 mg hydroalcoholic extract of watercress daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the phytochemical and biochemical properties of Watercress and its therapeutic effects in treating various human diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Watercress exhibits antioxidant, antibacterial, anticancer, anti-inflammatory, and organ-protective effects, and can help reduce complications of hypercholesterolemia and hyperglycemia. It also enhances antioxidant enzyme activity and reduces oxidative stress, DNA damage, and cancer susceptibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human applications inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ethanolic extract of Watercress (EENO) on bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis in rats, focusing on its antioxidant properties.
results_summary: Pre- or post-treatment with EENO attenuated pulmonary fibrosis by normalizing lung index, improving histological changes, and inhibiting collagen deposition. EENO also reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA and NO metabolites) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats (180-220 g)
study_duration: One week before and two weeks after bleomycin instillation (total of 3 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective effects of hydroalcoholic watercress extract against oxidative stress and liver injury in bile duct ligation-induced cholestatic rats.
results_summary: The hydroalcoholic extract of watercress significantly reduced liver protein oxidation and hydroxyproline levels, increased glutathione peroxidase activity, and attenuated hepatocyte necrosis in cholestatic rats. The findings suggest watercress extract may be beneficial for mitigating cholestatic liver damage through antioxidative and free-radical scavenging effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with bile duct ligation-induced cholestasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of post-packaging gamma radiation treatment in preserving total folates (vitamin B9) in watercress during refrigerated storage.
results_summary: In watercress, irradiation up to 5 kGy reduced folate loss after 7 days of storage, suggesting potential benefits for preservation. However, the study also indicated that preservation efficacy may vary depending on the plant matrix and irradiation dose.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on plant material, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the antihyperlipidemic and antidiabetic effects of hydroalcoholic extract of watercress leaves in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that watercress extract significantly reduced serum glucose, total cholesterol, and LDL-cholesterol in diabetic rats, demonstrating hypoglycemic and hypolipidemic effects. The effects were dose-dependent, with the 200 mg/kg dose showing notable efficacy.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.
effective_dosage: 100 and 200 mg/kg daily in drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of watercress methanol extract in inhibiting citrus green mould (Penicillium digitatum) and improving postharvest quality of orange fruits.
results_summary: Watercress extract showed 45.08% mycelia growth inhibition and reduced citrus fruit decay by up to 73%, demonstrating significant antifungal activity against Penicillium digitatum. The extract was particularly effective compared to dog rose extracts.
population_specificity: Citrus fruits (in vivo study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute and chronic watercress supplementation could reduce exercise-induced oxidative stress, specifically DNA damage and lipid peroxidation.
results_summary: Watercress supplementation (both acute and chronic) attenuated exercise-induced DNA damage and lipid peroxidation, reduced H₂O₂ accumulation, and increased lipid-soluble antioxidants compared to control phases.
population_specificity: Ten healthy male subjects (age 23 ± 4 years, stature 179 ± 10 cm, body mass 74 ± 15 kg).
study_duration: Acute (single dose 2 hours before exercise) and chronic (8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential synergistic antibacterial effects of watercress extracts and 2-phenylethyl isothiocyanate when combined with a standard antibiotic against extended-spectrum β-lactamases-Escherichia coli.
results_summary: The study found that combining watercress extracts or 2-phenylethyl isothiocyanate with an antibiotic increased antibacterial activity, with the most notable synergy observed between the antibiotic and 2-phenylethyl isothiocyanate. These results suggest watercress and its compounds could enhance antibiotic performance against resistant E. coli strains.
population_specificity: 11 isolates of extended-spectrum β-lactamases-Escherichia coli (in vitro study).
interactions: Synergistic interaction with a standard antibiotic noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunomodulatory effects of watercress extract on hematological and immunological parameters in rainbow trout.
results_summary: The study found that a 1% watercress extract supplementation improved hematological (Hb, MCHC) and immunological (lysozyme, complement activity, total protein, globulin) parameters in rainbow trout compared to controls.
population_specificity: Rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)
effective_dosage: 0.1% and 1% watercress extract per 1 kg of food

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of watercress extract on cell viability and its potential antigenotoxic properties against oxidative damage.
results_summary: The study found no differences in cell viability between control and treated groups, and significant antigenotoxic effects were observed at both concentrations tested, with damage reductions of 67.1-75.2%.
population_specificity: Peripheral blood cells (in vitro model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the oxidative effects of lead exposure on watercress by measuring antioxidant enzyme activities and lipid peroxidation levels in stems and leaves.
results_summary: The study found that lead exposure increased lipid peroxidation and altered antioxidant enzyme activities in watercress, with higher effects in stems than leaves. The highest lipid peroxidation occurred at 500 mg/L Pb, while enzyme activities peaked at varying lead concentrations (200 mg/L for SOD and GR, 250 mg/L for CAT, and 100 mg/L for AP).
population_specificity: Watercress (Nasturtium officinale R. Br.) grown in hydroponic culture.
effective_dosage: Lead acetate concentrations of 0, 50, 100, 200, 250, and 500 mg/L Pb.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether watercress consumption could reduce cancer risk by inducing detoxification enzymes in a genotype-dependent manner, using both in vitro and in vivo models.
results_summary: In vitro, watercress extract and PEITC increased gene expression and activity of detoxification enzymes (GPX1 and SOD2). In vivo, watercress consumption led to a small but significant increase in GPX and SOD enzyme activity in red blood cells, particularly in individuals with the GSTM1*0 genotype.
population_specificity: Human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) in vitro; human subjects in vivo.
effective_dosage: 85 g watercress per day in vivo; 0.1-10 microL/mL watercress extract (8.2 g WC per 1 mL extract) or 1-10 microM PEITC in vitro.
study_duration: 8 weeks in vivo; 24 hours in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying levels of nitrogen (N) and sulfur (S) fertility affect watercress biomass production, tissue composition, and concentrations of glucosinolates and carotenoids.
results_summary: Watercress shoot biomass, tissue %N, and C/N ratios were influenced by N but not S. Carotenoid and chlorophyll pigment concentrations responded to N but not S. Glucosinolate concentrations were affected by both N and S, with specific glucosinolates responding differently to each nutrient.
population_specificity: Watercress plants grown in nutrient solution culture.
effective_dosage: Three S levels (8, 16, 32 mg/L) and three N levels (6, 56, 106 mg/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a shoot multiplication system for watercress to improve its genetic characteristics and achieve frequent generation of transgenic plants.
results_summary: The study found that pre-treatment of internodes for 7 days promoted organogenesis, with over 90% of pre-treated explants producing multiple shoots. Transgenic watercress plants were successfully generated using particle bombardment and Agrobacterium-mediated transformation techniques.
population_specificity: In vitro watercress (Nasturtium officinale R. Br.) internode explants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of watercress supplementation on biomarkers related to cancer risk, including DNA damage and antioxidant status, in healthy adults.
results_summary: Watercress supplementation reduced basal DNA damage and oxidative purine DNA damage, particularly in smokers, and increased plasma lutein and beta-carotene levels. The results suggest watercress may lower cancer risk by reducing DNA damage and enhancing antioxidant status.
population_specificity: 30 men and 30 women (30 smokers and 30 nonsmokers), aged 19-55 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether watercress consumption affects acetaminophen metabolism, specifically its oxidative metabolites.
results_summary: Watercress ingestion significantly reduced plasma and urinary levels of oxidative acetaminophen metabolites (Cys-acetaminophen and mercapturate acetaminophen) by 21-55%, but did not alter non-oxidative metabolites (acetaminophen glucuronide and sulfate).
population_specificity: Human volunteers (n=7)
study_duration: Single dose (10 hours before acetaminophen administration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether watercress affects the metabolism of chlorzoxazone, a probe for CYP2E1 activity, in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: Watercress ingestion significantly increased the area under the chlorzoxazone plasma concentration-time curve by 56% and prolonged its elimination half-life by 53%, indicating inhibition of CYP2E1 activity. These effects were similar but less pronounced than those observed with isoniazid, a known CYP2E1 inhibitor.
population_specificity: 10 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a molluscicide (CuCl2) and predatory snail (Zonitoides nitidus) in controlling snail populations in natural watercress beds.
results_summary: The treatment successfully eliminated Lymnea truncatula in 14 stations within one year and in the remaining three within two years. Other snail species were eliminated over varying durations, with Z. nitidus eventually disappearing from most beds.
population_specificity: Natural watercress beds and their snail populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of weighted blanket use on reducing insomnia severity in adults with higher-than-average sensory sensitivity.
results_summary: All participants showed reduced insomnia severity, improved sleep quality, and three participants increased sleep duration after using weighted blankets. The intervention appeared particularly beneficial for those with self-reported anxiety.
population_specificity: Adults with moderate to severe insomnia and much higher sensory sensitivity than average.
study_duration: Two weeks of weighted blanket use

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential effectiveness of weighted blankets as a non-pharmacological intervention for managing periodic limb movement disorder (PLMD).
results_summary: The patient reported significant improvement in symptoms after using a weighted blanket alongside sleep hygiene education and lifestyle modifications. The case highlights the potential benefits of non-pharmacological interventions for PLMD but calls for further research on long-term efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: A 20-year-old female with periodic limb movement disorder (PLMD).

study_goal: To examine differences in sleep outcomes and adherence to weighted blankets (WBs) among children with ADHD over a 16-week intervention.
results_summary: Children who adhered to WB use (≥4 nights/week) showed early improvements in sleep, greater acceptance of the WB, and significant reductions in parent- and child-reported sleep problems compared to nonadherent children. Total sleep time remained stable for adherent children but decreased for nonadherent children.
population_specificity: Children with ADHD (n=94, mean age 9.0, range 6-14).
effective_dosage: Use of weighted blanket ≥4 nights/week (adherent group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the availability of weighted blankets reduced the need for protective stabilization during moderate sedation in pediatric dental visits.
results_summary: The study found that weighted blanket use significantly decreased protective stabilization from 78.7% to 32.8% and was associated with lower heart rate changes during treatment compared to cases without restraint. Age and weighted blanket use were key factors in reducing the need for restraint.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients undergoing moderate sedation in a university dental clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a remotely delivered weighted blanket intervention for people living with dementia and their caregivers, as well as the feasibility of collecting outcome measures.
results_summary: The study found high feasibility and acceptability of weighted blankets for people with dementia and their caregivers. Caregiver-completed outcome measures were feasible, but self-report measures by people with dementia were not.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling families living with dementia (21 people with dementia and their caregivers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a heavy weighted blanket (15-lb) compared to a light one (5-lb) could reduce chronic pain, mediated by improvements in anxiety and sleep.
results_summary: The heavy weighted blanket significantly reduced broad perceptions of chronic pain compared to the light blanket, particularly in individuals with high trait anxiety, but did not affect pain intensity ratings. The effect was not mediated by anxiety or sleep.
population_specificity: 94 adults with chronic pain.
effective_dosage: 15-lb (heavy) or 5-lb (light) weighted blanket, used overnight for one week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if using a weighted blanket at bedtime increases salivary concentrations of melatonin and oxytocin compared to a light blanket, and to assess effects on cortisol, salivary alpha-amylase activity, subjective sleepiness, and sleep duration.
results_summary: The study found a 32% higher increase in salivary melatonin with the weighted blanket compared to the light blanket, but no significant differences in oxytocin, cortisol, salivary alpha-amylase, subjective sleepiness, or sleep duration.
population_specificity: 26 young and healthy participants (15 men, 11 women).
effective_dosage: Weighted blanket (~12% of body weight) vs. light blanket (~2.4% of body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a weighted blanket decreases anxiety and/or anger in adult emergency department patients with preexisting psychiatric diagnoses.
results_summary: All groups showed reduced anxiety and anger scores, with greater decreases in the weighted blanket groups, though the small sample size prevented significant findings.
population_specificity: Adult emergency department patients with preexisting psychiatric diagnoses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure changes in sleep medication prescriptions and substance use disorder diagnoses before and after patients with psychiatric conditions received a weighted blanket.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant decrease in the use of common sleep medications (except melatonin, which increased slightly) and no increase in alcohol SUD diagnoses, though sedative SUD rates rose slightly. Younger age and certain psychiatric disorders were associated with reduced sleep medication use.
population_specificity: 1785 adults with psychiatric diagnoses in a Swedish region.
study_duration: One year of follow-up after a half-year wash-out period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the effects of exercise training on cognitive impairments and blood-brain barrier integrity in rats fed a Western Diet.
results_summary: The study found that a Western Diet combined with exercise training reduced locomotor and exploratory activities, induced short-term memory impairments, and altered blood-brain barrier integrity. However, delayed exercise intervention in obese rats stimulated protective processes like increased neurotrophins and lipid peroxidation markers.
population_specificity: Adult female Long Evans rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a warm weighted blanket could reduce preoperative anxiety and pain, as well as postsurgical restlessness, nausea, and vomiting in surgical patients.
results_summary: The study found that weighted blankets significantly reduced preoperative anxiety compared to traditional sheets or nonweighted blankets, but had no significant effect on presurgical pain or postsurgical nausea, vomiting, or restlessness.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing elective surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (use of a warm weighted blanket).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nanocellulose could modulate behaviors and glucose homeostasis in female mice on a Western diet through gut microbiome and immune modulation.
results_summary: CNF altered the gut microbiome and immune homeostasis, reduced diabetic incidences, but showed signs of insulin resistance and no effect on depressive-like behavior or grip strength. Beneficial microbiome changes were transient, disappearing after chronic consumption.
population_specificity: Female C57BL/6 and NOD mice (model for type 1 diabetes).
effective_dosage: 30 mg/kg/day for 30 days (initial study), followed by chronic 6-month study with CNF.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of bioactive peptides (EWYF and EWFY) on Western diet-induced metabolic-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD) in mice.
results_summary: The Western diet induced weight gain, liver damage, inflammation, and insulin resistance, which were significantly reversed by bioactive peptides in a dose-dependent manner. The peptides also mitigated oxidative stress and inflammation by targeting specific molecular pathways (NLRP3 inflammasome, TLR4/NF-κB, and Keap1/Nrf2/HO-1).
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-phosphate Western diet exacerbates CKD-MBD and induces vascular calcification in a mouse model of Alport CKD.
results_summary: The Western high-phosphate diet worsened CKD-MBD markers (hyperphosphatemia, elevated PTH and FGF23, reduced renal klotho) but did not induce vascular calcification in this CKD model. The diet also affected these markers in wild-type mice, suggesting broader impacts on phosphate homeostasis.
population_specificity: X-linked Col4a5 deficient murine homolog of Alport Syndrome (CKD) and wild-type littermates.
study_duration: Until disease progression equivalent to CKD stage 4-5 (exact duration not specified).
